aim: time trends of tb co-infection hiv
results: association of tb co-infection hiv and non-UK region of origin

aim: propose a model for tb screening
results: the proposed model could easily be implemented as a flexible way to screen for tb in newly arrived migrants

aim: development of the number of cases of  leishmaniasis in Lebanon
results: outbreak of leishmaniasis possibly due to influx of Syrian refugees

aim: yield of pre-entry screening programmes for active and latent tb
results: targeting high-prevalence countries and pre-entry screening should be considered

aim: describe the health of 48 Syrian asylum seekers
results: all were negative for hbv and hcv and hiv. Several unusual gram-negative bacteria species were isolated and ESBL/CPO and MRSA bacteria were found.

aim: incidence of new tb cases in Lebanon
results: the incidence were decreasing from 1999 to 2006 and increasing thereafter. The increase were mainly due to influx of Ethiopian and Syrian refugees

aim: investigate association between IGRA performance and age and co-morbidities in resettled African refugees
results: there was a significant and independent association of both age and number of comorbidities and IGRA performance

aim: evaluation of hbv screening of pregnant women
results: high hbv prevalence among migrants and refugees

aim: describe the population and health issues in migrants that recieved health screening
results: most frequent diseases were ltbi and eosinophilia and hbv. Among the rare diseases were infectious tb and malaria and soil-transmitted helminths

aim: explore knowledge about malaria transmission and protection in a Afghan refugee population
results: most afghan refugees did not use nets for self-protection.

aim: characterisation of sleeping patterns among populations at risk of anopheline biting
results: most afghan refugees did not use nets for self-protection.

aim: prevalence of LTBI in refugees
results: high prevalence in refugees from sub-Saharan Africa but much less likely to initiate treatment than refugees from Middle East
note: Although the population is extracted from the refugee Health Electronic Information System the article does not provide information on how an individual is included in this database (WHO-guidelines?). Tests with QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube

aim: describe demography and hiv risk behaviour among African migrants and refugees
results: risk factors were unprotected sex and having several sexual partners and previous STIs and lack of voluntary hiv testing

aim: examine the health literacy on TB among immigrants by global region of birth and helath insurance status
results: adults from asia had the lowest TB health literacy and adults from Europe the highest. Uninsured immigrants had lower TB health literacy

aim: review of health status and medical care among refugees and asylum seekers in Germany
results: most evidence on mental health and infectious diseases. Least evidence on chronic diseases and childhood illnesses and maternity health care

aim: review of policies to improve health care for asylum seekers and refugees in EU
results: very limited evidence. Most evidence on maternity and mental illness. The nature and length of the asylum process influence health. Recomendations to improve access and to examine the heatlh effects of different phases of the asylum process

aim: prevalence of hbv among Turkish immigrants
results: Turkish immigrants in Germany have a higher seroprevalence of hbv than the general population in Germany

aim: status of malaria cases in Auckland
results: 36 cases of malaria in 34 patients. 11 were residents of New Zealand . 11 were refugees and 10 were migrants

aim: comparison of basic characteristics of foreign-born and US-born hiv patients
results: foreign-born were younger more were women and heterosexual and less were substance useres

aim: describe health profile of resettled Iraqi refugees
results: 14.1% had ltbi and 24.6% were obese and 15.2% had hypertension. The prevailing disease group were noninfectious
note: reports on both communicable and noncommunicable diseases

aim: characterise HCV epidemiology in the Levant
results: HCV prevalence in the general population were 0.2% in Iraq and Lebanon; 0.3% in Jordan; 0.4% in Syria. Genotype 1 and 4 were dominant
note: the study aim is not concerned with migrant populations

aim: compare pre- and post-entry tb screening of people migrating to Israel
results: systematic screening of active tb should be considered for migrants from high-prevalence countries to low-prevalence
note: a commentary to the article by Aldridge et al.

aim: assess the prevalence of tb and hiv and hbv in asylum seekers and refugees in UK
results: few studies have been conducted on the diseases of interest. Prevalence per 1000 were found to be: tb 1.33 to 10.42; hbv from 57 to 118; hiv 38.19

aim: estimate hbv prevalence in a migrant population
results: prevalence in the study population were generally lower than that of the country of origin and lower than elsewhere reported and below the set cost effectiveness threshold for general screening. Thus only targeted screening are recommended

aim: describe the clinical impact of hv screening programmes for migrants from China
results: hbv screening in Chinese migrants may have several positive concequences

aim: demographic and clinical characteristics of immigrants and local hbv infected patients
results: most immigrants came from East Europe were younger more had hdv coinfection

aim: case study of public health strategy for TB among Syrian refugees in Jordan
results: a high incidence rate was found. A partnership between local and international health organisations were formed with the potential to improve diagnoses and treatment

aim: screening of undocumented immigrants for hbv hcv and hiv
results: both hbv hcv and hiv rates were high in most subgroups of undocumented immigrants

aim: measure trends in hiv-related behaviour over time in a post-conflict long-term refugee camp
results: the prevalence of unprotected sex and having multiple partners were no different among residents in the refugee camp compared to the host population and lower than during the conflict

aim: examine the cost-effectiveness of preventive treatment for tb
results: preventive therapy of LTBI may be important in migrants from hig-prevalence regions but there is no consistent evidence for its cost-effectiveness

aim: prevalence of hiv-hbv coinfection
results: there was a low prevalence of hbv-hiv coinfection

aim: intervention to improve hiv knowledge
results: the intervention worked: an incresed knowledge of hiv and a more positive attutude toward condoms were reported

aim: prevalence of malaria in resettled  pregnant women
results: the prevalence were 9.1%

aim: Risk of transmission of vector borne diseases following the possible introduction by migrants or travellers in areas with competent vectors in the EU/EEA.
note: rapid risk assessment

aim: The occurrence of shigellosis among refugees is not unexpected because shigellosis is endemic in the countries they originate from, as well as in some of the countries they travel through.
note: rapid risk assessment

aim: Cutaneous diphtheria is a potentialrisk factor for transmission of diphtheria.
note: rapid risk assessment

aim: The information available indicates that most of the 27 cases are likely to have been exposed to body lice infestations and louse-borne relapsing fever during their journey to Europe.
note: rapid risk assessment

aim: technical report to complement and introduce the migrant health disease-specific reports. The purpose of the background note is to provide an overview of migration and infectious diseases in the EU
note: technical report

aim: prevalence of hbv and feasibility of screening of undocumented migrants
results: point-of-care screening were accept by most and is very much feasible in an undocumented migrant population

aim: describe common syndromes and communicable diseases and vaccination status in newly arrived migrants
results: most common were respiratory infections and myalgia. tb 7.8%; hiv 0.3%; hbv 3.2; hcv 0.8%. Vaccinated against poliomyelitis 22.3%

aim: examine misclassification of tb in a migrant population
results: there is much misclassification when testing potential immigrants pre-entry

aim: estimate the proportion of migrants that were tested for hbv and explore GP testing practice
results: only 12% of eligible were tested for hbv. Most Gps did not use guidelines to inform hbv testing in migrants

aim: prevalence of hbv among immigrants and comparison of patient characteristics to Italian patients
results: immigrants were younger and predominantly female and more often inactive hbv carriers and less had genotype D. Fewer immigrants had liver morbidities and fewer recieved antiviral treatment

aim: prevalence of ltbi in refugees and proportion who completed treatment post-arrival
results: Only 47% and 30% started and finished treatment for ltbi respectively

aim: trends in travel related infections
results: infectious diseases is a public health concern in Europa that should be addressed with information and prophylaxis
note: only infectious diseases

aim: seroprevalence of HCV in migrants living in low HCV prevalence, high migrant-receiving countries
health risk to autochthonous caused by immigration
results: there is very limited risk of spread to the autochthonous people

aim: NA
results: NA

aim: discusses the epidemiology of infectious diseases in relation to migration from high- to low-prevalence countries
results: migration will have an impact on the disease epidemiology and migrants will be an increasingly important risk group. To combat these diseases a global perspective must be adopted
note: a general discussion on migration and infectious diseases

aim: test of new method to detect hiv and ltbi and hbv and hcv
results: only ltbi were detected more frequently with the new method. Very few migrants presented to clinics to have diagnostics

aim: examine the positive and the negative predictive value of QuantiFERON-TB Gould test and tuberculin skin test in asylum seeker population
results: the PPV were 3.3% and the NPV were 99.8%. For tuberculin skin test the PPV were 2.3% and NPV were 99.1%

aim: assess follow-up of tb screening results in an asylum seekers population
results: only 1% of asylum seekers with a diagnosis of ltbi recieved treatment and long delays were observed until treatment was initiated.

aim: intervention to improve follow-up after tb diagnosis
results: the intervention improved the follow-up

aim: prevalence of hbv and hcv in a migrant population
results: the prevalence of both hbv and hcv were around 2%. There was a lack of knowledge about transmission
note: also includes stratification on educational level and year of immigration and family status. Includes prevalence of vaccination

aim: identify patterns in country of origin and corss-border movement of TB within EU
results: Germany and Italy reported the most TB cases from other EU countries. Poland and Romania gave rise to the largest population of migrant TB cases within EU

aim: all-cause mortality and main causes of death in different migrant populations living in EU
results: most migrant populations had higher mortality from infectious diseases (tb and hiv). Cancer mortality generally low execpt liver and stomach cancer for specific regions. CVD and diabetes mortality in general higher.
note: very heterogenic pattern

aim: prevalence of hbv and hcv and alcoholic liver disease and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
results: immigrants from EU-countries or neighbouring countries had higher prevalence of hbv and hcv infections. Immigrants from Africa and Asia had low prevalence for both

aim: prevalence of hbv in Bahrain
results: overall prevalence was 0.58%. the prevalence was higher among immigrants from India Pakistan Bangladesh Philippines Indonesia and Ethiopia

aim: cost-benefit comparison of overseas hbv screening programmes
results: overseas screening is cost-effective compared to vaccination only strategy

aim: risk of adverse obstretric and perinatal outcomes among refugee women
results: asylum seeker women had higher risk of delivery by Cesarian section as well as being hiv-positive; homeless and delayed access to prenatal care

aim: evaulate screening programmes for newly arrived migrants to EU
results: most common screening programme for tb and for targeted populations

aim: prevalence of hbv among internally displaced persons in Pakistan
results: hbv were highly prevalent in the study population

aim: assess tb in crisis-affected populations
results: there was a strong correlation between crisis in a country and the tb incidence or prevalence; equally for populations affected by crisis

aim: quantify and characterise migration-related TB to EU countries
results: an overall increase in the percentage of migrant TB cases was driven by decrease of native TB cases. In more than half of the migrant cases the country of origin were India; Pakistan; Somalia; Morocco; Turkey; Russia; Bangladesh; Philippines

aim: prevalence of tst-positive and degree of attendance and follow-up in a migrant population
results: the proportion of tst-positive were highest in refugees from Africa (53.7%) and East Asia (75%). Of 115 refugees referred to follow-up 53.1% presented to the clinic. Refugees from Near East/South Asia were least likely to attend follow-up.

aim: time trends in extrapulmonal tb
results: association of extrapulmonal tb and born outside UK

aim: PTSD in arab refugee women
results: a high percentage of arab refugee women had some form of PTSD

aim: prevalence of childhood chronic hbv infection
results: 50% of cases were immigrants

aim: test of hypothesis that G6PD defiency is protective against vivax malaria
results: G6PD is gives protection against vivax malaria infection

aim: prevalence of hbv and risk behaviour and vaccination among Lationo and Asian immigrants
results: Asian immigrants had the highest prevalence of both prior hbv infection and chronic infection. Latino immigrants had the lowest prevalence vaccination

aim: evaluate factors related to screening of hbv in Chinese Americans
results: the proposed model could be used to predict hbv screening in a Chinese American population

aim: health conditions in migrants
results: most common diagnoses were LTBI and tb and HBV (asian immigarnts) and hiv and malaria and schistosomiasis (african immigrants) and strongylidiasis

aim: STIs among female sex workers compared to general population
results: there was increase prevalence of some STIs in the group of sex workers. Migrant sex workers had better sexual health than native sex workers but had higher prevalence of non-STI health issues

aim: compare treatment adherence and virological outcomes among refugees and host communities
results: in general there were no differnce between the adherence or treatment outcome of refugees and the host communities

aim: prevalence of hbv and hcv among juvenile immigrants from Albania
results: the prevalence of hbv were high in the study population

aim: evaluation of tb programme in refugee camps
results: treatment outcomes depend on the programme's to respond to specific constraints

aim: health condition of Syrian refugees
results: most prevalent diseases were cutaneous leishmaniasis and tb and HBV and HCV
note: it is not clear in what stage of the migration the study population were examined: the article referes to refugees but it seems there are at least some asylum seekers in the population

aim: compare diagnostic delay and outcome of tb non-insured non-national immigrants with insured Israeli citizens
results: being migrant was associated with longer patient delay and worse therapy outcome

aim: prevalence of hbv in a refugee population
results: the overall prevalence of hbv were 10.7% Refugees contributed to 43.3% of all hbv infection positives

aim: examine impact of debrifing as a strategy against burnout among mental health service providers
results: spirituality may both serve as protective factor and increase compassion among menatl helath service providers

aim: immigrant students knowledge about tb
results: many had been assessed for tb screening upon immigration but few had good understanding of tb symptoms, disease and treatment.

aim: compare mortality from infectious diseases among refugees and natives
results: higher mortality of infectious diseases among migrants compared to natives

aim: prevalence of active tb or ltbi among immigrants with some evidence of tb or considered at high risk for developing tb
results: most immigrants came from Nepal and Philippines and Ethiopia. 4% were diagnosed with active tb and 53% with ltbi. Almost all recieved an completed therapy

aim: factors associated with the use of insecticide treated nets among pregnant women in a camp for internally displaced persons
results: only 35% of pregnant women had used the nets. Factors associated with the use were knowledge about the nets and willingsness to purchase one. Adverse factors were divorce/widow/single and hours taken to reach helath centre

aim: burden of tb in EU
results: 25% of tb cases in 2010 in migrants (range: 0.2% to 85.5%); although decrease in general pop. this is not reflected in migrant subpop. (six countries are execptions); native-tb-cases and migrant-tb-cases differ in SES
note: discussion about path of transmission in migrants vs natives

aim: assess demographics and burden of disease in migrants living in Maltese open centres
results: most had spend many years in transit before arrival; few infectious diseases; a small number developed active tb while in the centre;
note: low mirbidity burden but social inequalities migration process itself put the health physical mental and social well-being at risk. Especially in hosting and transit countries migrants health is often threatened

aim: tb burden in low-prevalence countries; different screening methodsincl. cost-eff.
results: tb usually seen in migrant pop. caused by interaction and reactivation; little transmition to reciving country; common: screening for active tb; increasingly LTBI from high-prev. countries
note: dsicussion about active vs latent tb and cost-eff. of each

aim: describe hiv in young people living in post-crisis transit camps
results: hiv prevalence among women were 15.6% and associated with practicing dry sex and 9.9% among males and associated with non-consensual sexual debut

aim: identify risk factors for TB among native- and foregin-born patients + barriers to management of foreign cases
results: risk factors differed between native and foreign born. The outcome and time to diagnoses were similar. Most important barrieres were language and fear of deporatation

aim: immunisation coverage among children
results: overall immunisation coverage of traditional vaccines were above 90%. Administration of boosters were delayed. Immigrant status were associated with risk of incomplete and delayed vaccination amongst other for hbv

aim: describe characteristics and indications for treatment of chronic hbv in a cohort of immigrants
results: the prevalence of chronic hbv infection were 10.6%. There was an association with sub-Sahran Africa country of birth

aim: prevalence of hbv in Central Italy
results: because of increased immigration to EU countries an increase in the prevalence of hbv can be inspected

aim: intervention to provide community education on hbv infection
results: the programme may serve as a useful prototype

aim: prevalence of hbv and liver cancer in Asian immigrants
results: Asian immigrants in New York have increased hbv prevalence and are at risk of liver cancer

aim: tb epidemiology in immigrants
results: compared to native cases immigrant tb cases were younger; more likely to be female; more likely to have extrapulmonary tb; more likely to have multidrug resistent tb. Most common country of origin were Somalia and Russia.

aim: prevalence of hbv and hdv and hcv in Greenlanders in Denmark and in Greenland
results: there were no difference in the occurence

aim: identify groups of high risk of HBV infection to guide control strategies in immigrant-receiving countries
results: high seroprevalence of chronic HBV in migrants from most world regions.
note: discusses targeted vaccination of migrants to control HBV

aim: cost-effectiveness analysis of hbv screening and vaccination in migrant populations
results: screening was cost-effective in migrants from high prevalence countries. Thus screening was not cost-effective in migrants from Middle East or Latin America

aim: health of refugee children less than 5 years of age
results: most common infection were ltbi and parasitic infection (15%). 50% and 59% were immune to rubella and measles

aim: factors associated with ltbi
results: factors associated with ltbi were country of origin and travel conditions and marital status and cough and age and prior tb exposure

aim: evaluate the completion of treatment of tb in immigrant population
results: it may be possible to obtain high completion rate of treatment by following several recommendations

aim: comparison of x-ray and interview in detecting tb.
results: for x-ray: sensitivity of 100% and specificity of 89.9%. For interview: sensitivity of 55% and specificity of 96% If effectiveness is the main objective x-ray is the best tool. However interview has advantages in flexibility and cost and the burden for both patient and health care system
note: Also reports prevalence of tb in the population

aim: prevalence of ltbi in migrant population
results: in total 24% of immigrants had positive QFT-IT with highest prevalences among migrants from Liberia and Bhutan and Burma
note: places immigrants into categories according to the prevalence in the general population in the country of birth

aim: prevalence of syphilis and chlamydia and gonorrhea and hiv
results: overall prevalence for syphilis were 1.1% and for chlamydia 0.6% and for gonorrhea 0.2% and for hiv 2.0%. For co-infections the prevalence were 0.1%

aim: comparison of two programmes for diagnosis and follow-up
results: 2.7% of refugees were confirmed with ltbi and none with active tb

aim: prevalence of hbv and hcv and hiv and syphilis among refugees
results: the prevalence of hbv were 8.3% and of hcv 4.5% and of hiv 1.5% and of syphilis < 1.5%

aim: evaluation of hbv educational programme to Asian immigrants
results: the educational programme showed effect on the knowledge of hbv but limited effect on the testing levels

aim: prevalence of hbv and hcv and hiv in a migrant population
results: the prevalence of hbv were 10.7% and of hcv 5.6% and of hiv 4%
note: twin-study to Tramuto 2013

aim: prevalence of hbv and hcv and hiv in a migrant population
results: the prevalence of hbv infection (any marker) were 23.6% and of hcv 5.6% and of hiv 4.6%
note: twin-study to Tramuto 2012

aim: prevalence of ltbi in refugees and rates of treatment acceptance and completion
results: 31.9% had ltbi. Old age and male sex and Eastern Mediterranean region of birth were associated with increased risk. Of 146 diagnosed with ltbi 121 were offered treatment and 93 accepted. 10 did not show for follow-up and 15 were not offered treatment. Only 44.1% (41) completed treatment

aim: assess the demography and clinical status of migrants arriving after travel over sea
results: great differences between migrants from Africa and from near East; CVD and diabetes were common in Near Easterns; skin disease had high prevalence in migrants from Africa; Migrants attributed their symptomps to the journey
note: no public health risk were detected

aim: prevalence of hbv infection and evaluation of a method for evaluating hbv infection distribution
results: the overall hbv infection prevalence were 2.3%

aim: socio-cognitive and socio-cultural determinants for hbv screening
results: relevant socio-cultural belifs were shame stigma the association of screening with sexuality and family values

aim: estimate effect of screening and treatment of LTBI of selected immigrants
results: screening and treatment of LTBI in immigrants from high TB incidence countries is the most effective strategy

aim: molecular biology of hbv in chronically infected migrant population
results: migrants are likely to be infected pre-migration

aim: report of 12 cases of tb in asylum seekers from low incidence countries  arriving to Netherlands in 2015
results: 7 cases from Syria; 3 from Iraq; 1 from Bosnia; 1 from Macedonia

aim: time trend of malaria and tb and hiv and enteric fever
results: country of birth is a risk factor for infection
note: associates migrant waves with prevalence of infectious diseases

aim: cause of death and comp. risk in migrants vs. native. Confirming immigrant health transition theory
results: low all-cause mortality among immigrants driven by lower mortality from chronic diseases
note: concludes on the immigrant helath transition proposed in Spallek 2011 but have no data on length of stay in country of resid.  or type of immigrant (refugee, labour migrant etc)

aim: compare QuantiFERON-TB Gold and tuberculin test among foreign-born and homeless and hiv infected and drug abuse persons in testing for ltbi
results: QuantiFERON-TB may improve diagnostics of ltbi in foreign-born and older persons and may be at par with tuberculin skin test in hiv-infected

aim: access to health care for pregnent women comparison between undocumented migrants and Danish residents
results: undocumented migrants have limited access compared to Danish residents

aim: editorial on how to address TB and LTBI in high incidence  countries
results: screening of all immigrants from moderate to high incidence countries may be the most cost-effective option
note: editorial

aim: design and evaluate tb education video
results: adult education centres may be used as location for tb education

aim: evaluation of screening and vaccination programmes
results: there is a need for health departments to support doctors' delivery of screening and vaccination to people at high risk of hbv infection

aim: long term clinical outcomes in hiv infected refugees compared to nonrefugees
results: refugees were less adherent beyond year 3 after diagnosis. Refugees had higher odds of viremia following undetected viral loads

aim: burden of chronic hbv infection among immigrants
results: chronic hbv infected lost 4.6 life years on avarage at baseline and had an increased lifetime medical cost of 24249 canadian dollars as well as a range of liver ralated morbidities
note: estimates the prevalence of chronic hbv infection in the immigrant population by multiplying the number of immigrants from a specific country with the prevalence in that country

aim: explores associations between knowledge of hiv and hiv-avoidant behaviour
results: reasons for hiv risk behaviour may be context specific

aim: knowledge and behaviors towards hbv and hbv vaccine in an immigrant population
results: around half of participants did not know about hbv or its transmission
